book.title: Regular Tessellations and hyperbolic Geometry
book.subtitle: An Approach by Constructions (without Terms and Formulas)

chapter.title: Regular Tessellations

introduction.p: We start by considering which regular tessellations can exist in the Euclidean plane and ask whether there could be other regular tessellations in other geometries. We answer this question (for the time being) with a picture in which the regular tessellations of spherical, Euclidean and hyperbolic geometry are summarized and take this as a motivation to start looking for hyperbolic geometry.

chapter.section:
Regular Tessellations in the Euclidean Plane
A tessellation (or tiling) of the Euclidean plane is a covering of the whole plane with one or more geometric shapes, called tiles, with no overlaps an no gaps. The following figures show four selected tessellations of the Euclidean plane.
More precisely, a tessellation (or tiling) of the Euclidean plane \mathbb{R}^2 is a locally finite familiy (U_i)_{i\in I} of bounded open sets U_i\subset \mathbb{R}^2 such that these open sets does not intersect pairwise (U_i \cap U_j = \emptyset for all i\neq j \in I) and the union of the closures \overline{U_i}, the tiles, fill the whole plane (i.e. \cup_{i\in I}\overline{U_i} = \mathbb{R}^2). Locally finite means that every circle intersects only with finitely many of the \overline{U_i}
The semiregular (3, 3, 4, 3, 4)-tessellation
The Cairo pentagonal tessellation
The semiregular (4, 6, 12)-tessellation
A tesselation with squares
The tessellations in consist of regular 3- and 4-gons. consist of regular 4-, 6- and 12-gons. Tessellations consisting of regular polygons are called semiregular tessellations. In the Euclidean plane there are exactly eight semiregular tesselations (see for a more precise definition and a proof).
The tessellation in is called the Cairo pentagonal tessellation, since it can be found on streets in Cairo and since it consists of congruent pentagons. The Cairo pentagonal tessellation is dual to the semiregular (3, 3, 4, 3, 4)-tessellation in (you get it by connecting the centers of adjacent tiles).

In the (3, 3, 4, 3, 4)-tessellation, two edges of a triangle coincide with an edge of a adjacent square, the third edge coincides with an edge of an adjacend triangle.
Even it is very interesting (and not easy at all) to understand tessellations in general, we will focus only on the so called regular ressellations. For this, we first remember the concept of the regular n-gon. In the following, n denotes a natural number \geq 3.
A regular n-gon or regular polygon in the Euclidean plane is a polygon consisting of n sides that is equiangular (all interior angles between neighboring sides are equal) and equilateral (all sides have the same length).
Regular 5-gon
The n vertices of a regular n-gon lie on a circle. The center angle, i.e. the angle between two neighoring vertices with the center of the circle, equals 360° / n. The interior angle (the interior angle between to neighboring sides) equals 180° - \frac{360°}{n}.
Show that the interior angle of a regular n-gon equals 180° - \frac{360°}{n}.
A regular n-tessellation of the Euclidean plane is a side-by-side covering with regular n-gons of the whole plane with no overlaps and no gaps. Side-by-side means, that every side of every regular n-gon coincides with exactly one side of another regular n-gon. For brevity we often omit the n and write regular tesselation.
In the Euclidean plane we all know the three following regular tessellations:
The regular (3,6)-tessellation of the Euc
The regular (4,4)-tessellation of the Euc
The regular (6,3)-tessellation of the Euc
We will show that there are no other regular tessellations of the Eulidean plane. For this we first formulate some basic propoerties of regular tesselations:
In a regular n-tessellation
all regular n-gons are congruent.
the number of joining n-gons in a vertice is the same for every vertice.
It is clear that two regular n-gons which have a common side are congruent. Let A and A' be two regular n-gons. Since the tessellation fills the whole plane it is possible to find a sequence A=A_1, A_2, ..., A_k=A' of n-gons such that two subsequent n-gons share a common side. Hence A and B are congruent.
Let m be the number of n-gons coming together in any corner. Since all occuring n-gons are congruent, the interior angle of any of these n-gon must equal \frac{360°}{m}. Or, inversely, the number m of congruent n-gons coming together in any vertice must equal 360°/\alpha, where \alpha is the interior angle of the congruent n-gons.
In the following we denote by m\geq 3 the number of n-gons comming together in every vertice of a regular tessellation and denote such a regular tesselation as a regular (n,m)-tessellation.
For a regular (n,m)-tessellation of the Euclidean plane, the equation \frac{1}{n} + \frac{1}{m} = \frac{1}{2} holds. The only solutions (for natural n,m\geq 3) to this equation are the (n,m)-pairs (3,6), (4,4) and (6,3). Hence the three tessellations shown in , and are the only regular tessallation in the Eulidean plane.
The interior angle of a regular n-gon in the Euclidean plane equals \alpha := 180° - \frac{360°}{n}. Since m regular n-gons are coming together in a corner, we have 360° = m\cdot \alpha = m\cdot ( 180° - \frac{360°}{n}). After dividing by m\cdot 360° and bringing \frac{1}{n} to the other side, we have \frac{1}{n} + \frac{1}{m} = \frac{1}{2}.

introduction.p: We deal with Euclidean line reflections and recognize that these are something like the atomic building blocks of Euclidean geometry.
We define points, lines and angles in the Poincaré model of hyperbolic geometry.
We define the circle inversion in the Euclidean plane and work out important constructions and properties of this surprising and at the same time intuitive mapping.

chapter.title: Hyperbolic line reflections, perpendicular Bisectors and Circles

introduction.p: We learn how the hyperbolic line through two hyperbolic points can be constructed by circle inversion. Then we define the reflection on a hyperbolic line - of course also with circle inversion. With the tool of hyperbolic line reflection we are then able to introduce the hyperbolic perpendicular bisector and a kind of hyperbolic distance. We use this to define hyperbolic circles and to classify them completely.
We construct the hyperbolic regular tessellations - with what has been worked out so far, this is pleasantly simple and intuitive.
We compare essential properties of spherical, Euclidean and hyperbolic geometry.
We take a look at selected aspects of the history of hyperbolic geometry.

appendix.title: Semiregular Tessellations in the Euclidean Plane

introduction.p: We show that there are exactly eight semiregular tessellations in the Euclidean plane.

appendix.title: Line Reflections are the atomic building Blocks of Euclidean Geometry

introduction.p: We show that every distance preserving map in the Euclidean plane is a product of at most three line reflections.
